Title: Linking forum posts - warhol-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
Warhol's film making endeavors have come up in this course, but nothing about his attempts at acting in film himself. A few years ago I found this very strange Italian-made Liz Taylor movie on a bargain-bin DVD. It's titled 'The Driver's Seat,' but was originally released in 1974 as 'Identikit.' Andy Warhol has a small part in the film playing a British nobleman with a fake accent (the voice sounds dubbed). The plot revolves around a middle-aged woman (Taylor) who goes on vacation to look for the perfect man to murder her. She meets Warhol's character in an airport and considers him to do the job; but then on meeting him again she rejects him as 'not my type.' The movie is really terribly awful, so much so that I believe Taylor suppressed its showing in the U.S. (but fun to watch, nevertheless). Here are Warhol's two scenes: Part I http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KoqCeJ_X4mw Part II http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-fSGiSdkE_I Here's an article mentioning the film: http://www.slantmagazine.com/house/2013/25/sinful-cinema-the-drivers-seat I haven't found any commentary from Warhol himself about the film--why he did it, what he felt about his role, etc. I did, however, find some references to Warhol's role on a 1980s TV show, 'The Love Boat.' Apparently, he was a nervous actor and felt he didn't do a very good job. That episodes been removed from YouTube. Wonder why. Anyone else have comments or information about Warhol as an actor?

That was a wonderful interview piece. As a film fan I wanted to throw in a couple of references into the discussion. I think it is fascinating to think about filmmakers who have seemingly been inspired by Warhol, and during the discussion about Eva, the Factory-created star who wrote an 'autobiographical semi-fictional' book, the thing that immediately jumped into my mind is the whole controversy around J.T. LeRoy. ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JT_LeRoy ) LeRoy came to prominence after writing a number of apparently semi-autobiographical novels about drug addiction, prostitution and abuse, and had a relationship with Gus Van Sant, producing Elephant and featuring in an interview on the Criterion edition of Van Sant's film My Own Private Idaho (itself about male prostitution). His novel The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things was also made into a film. He also appeared in a film documentary on Warhol in 2005. 2005 was the year in which J.T. LeRoy was revealed as actually being a pen name for Laura Albert, which caused a lot of controversy as a lot of the J.T. LeRoy novels had been taken as autobiographical, despite always being fictional creations. The whole controversy raised a whole interesting set of questions about whether you can be reach deeper into subjects through mediation, and whether the gaze of celebrity media inevitably becomes a destructive one, constantly searching out the 'flaws in the story'. ___ The other reference I wanted to point out is that Fiontan Moran briefly mentioned Mary Woronov in Chelsea Girls but kind of dismissed her career beyond that. I think there would be a lot of cult movie or horror film fans who would disagree about the idea that Woronov didn't break out to become a celebrity in her own right (albeit a cult one!). Many of the films she is in were directed by Paul Bartel, who was kind of her Warhol-muse figure for this period! She turns up in the cult Bartel film Death Race 2000 (opposite Sylvester Stallone!) and almost entirely dominated the cult horror scene in the 1980s, from classic counterculture comedy (also directed by Bartel and recently given the prestigious honour of being inducted into the Criterion Collection of classic films) Eating Raoul, through to day-glo hper-stylised pop culture pieces such as Chopping Mall, TerrorVision and Night of the Comet! She has been relatively quiet in the 90s and 2000s (despite appearing in a great cameo in the live action Looney Tunes movie directed by Joe Dante and in Gregg Araki's early feature The Living End, both of which are filmmakers who perfectly fit her larger than life persona!), but recently had a role in The House of The Devil, which is one of the key ur-texts for the recent horror film revival. I'm not certain how applicable either observation is for this Warhol course, but both of those tangents came to mind while watching the excellent interview.

I thought the first video posed an interesting contradiction regarding Warhol's source material. It pointed out that, early in Warhol's career, he 'appropriated' his materials from photographs that others had taken of celebrities. As Prof. Davis stated, this fit in very well with work that other Pop artists were doing at the time. However, as Warhol became a celebrity himself, he started using his own pictures he was able to take of celebrities. This makes me question the value of his first works of art more--was it a conscious effort to make a statement about celebrity culture and appropriation, or was he merely using other people's photographs because he was not able to have the access to take his own?

Input.threadtitle: The change in Warhol's source material for celebrities
Input.posts:
I thought the first video posed an interesting contradiction regarding Warhol's source material. It pointed out that, early in Warhol's career, he 'appropriated' his materials from photographs that others had taken of celebrities. As Prof. Davis stated, this fit in very well with work that other Pop artists were doing at the time. However, as Warhol became a celebrity himself, he started using his own pictures he was able to take of celebrities. This makes me question the value of his first works of art more--was it a conscious effort to make a statement about celebrity culture and appropriation, or was he merely using other people's photographs because he was not able to have the access to take his own?
